title: Song of Solomon Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Song of Solomon chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Song of Solomon Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Song of Solomon Chapter 2.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 2:1, what two flowers does the speaker compare herself to?
options: Rose of Sharon and lily of the valleys
Lily of the valleys and daisy
questions.correctAnswer: Rose of Sharon and lily of the valleys
questions.explanation: The speaker says, 'I am the rose of Sharon, and the lily of the valleys,' directly naming these two flowers.

questions.question: According to Song of Solomon 2:3, the beloved is compared to which tree among the trees of the wood?
questions.correctAnswer: Apple tree
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'As the apple tree among the trees of the wood, so is my beloved among the sons.'

questions.question: What does the beloved bring the speaker to in Song of Solomon 2:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Banqueting house
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'He brought me to the banqueting house.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Song of Solomon 2:5: 'Stay me with _______, comfort me with apples: for I am sick of love.'
questions.correctAnswer: flagons
questions.explanation: The verse reads, 'Stay me with flagons, comfort me with apples.'

questions.question: According to Song of Solomon 2:6, where is the beloved's left hand?
questions.correctAnswer: Under my head
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'His left hand is under my head.'

questions.question: Who does the speaker charge not to stir up or awake her love in Song of Solomon 2:7?
questions.correctAnswer: Daughters of Jerusalem
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'I charge you, O ye daughters of Jerusalem... that ye stir not up, nor awake my love.'

questions.question: True or False: In Song of Solomon 2:8, the beloved comes leaping upon the plains and valleys.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The verse states he is 'leaping upon the mountains, skipping upon the hills,' not plains and valleys.

questions.question: How is the beloved described in Song of Solomon 2:9?
options: Like a roe or a young hart
Like a lion and a king
questions.correctAnswer: Like a roe or a young hart
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'My beloved is like a roe or a young hart.'

questions.question: What does the beloved say to the speaker in Song of Solomon 2:10?
options: Rise up, my love, my fair one, and come away
Sing with me in the fields
questions.correctAnswer: Rise up, my love, my fair one, and come away
questions.explanation: The verse records the beloved saying, 'Rise up, my love, my fair one, and come away.'

questions.question: True or False: According to Song of Solomon 2:11, the winter is ongoing and the rain is beginning.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'the winter is past, the rain is over and gone,' indicating the opposite.

questions.question: According to Song of Solomon 2:12, what birds' voices are heard in the land?
options: The singing of birds and the voice of the turtle
questions.correctAnswer: The singing of birds and the voice of the turtle
questions.explanation: The verse mentions, 'the time of the singing of birds is come, and the voice of the turtle is heard.'

questions.question: What does the fig tree do in Song of Solomon 2:13?
questions.correctAnswer: Putteth forth her green figs
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'The fig tree putteth forth her green figs.'

questions.question: Where does the dove dwell according to Song of Solomon 2:14?
options: In the clefts of the rock, in the secret places of the stairs
questions.correctAnswer: In the clefts of the rock, in the secret places of the stairs
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'O my dove, that art in the clefts of the rock, in the secret places of the stairs.'

questions.question: True or False: Song of Solomon 2:15 talks about taking the little foxes that spoil the vines.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'Take us the foxes, the little foxes, that spoil the vines.'

questions.question: What is the relationship between the speaker and the beloved in Song of Solomon 2:16?
options: My beloved is mine, and I am his
My beloved is far away from me
My beloved is unknown to me
questions.correctAnswer: My beloved is mine, and I am his
questions.explanation: The verse states clearly, 'My beloved is mine, and I am his.'

medium.title: Song of Solomon Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Song of Solomon Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 2:1 teach us about humility and contentment in Christian life?
options: By recognizing oneself as a simple flower among many
By boasting about one's own beauty
By comparing oneself to a lion among sheep
By seeking to be above others
questions.correctAnswer: By recognizing oneself as a simple flower among many
questions.explanation: The verse uses humble imagery of the rose and lily to express simple beauty and contentment, teaching believers to embrace humility and be content with their God-given identity (Song of Solomon 2:1; 1 Peter 5:5; Philippians 4:11).

questions.question: A believer is feeling unloved and isolated. Based on Song of Solomon 2:2-3, what biblical truth would you share about God's love and our value?
options: God values us uniquely, like a lily among thorns and an apple tree among wood
We are just ordinary and unnoticed by God
Love is conditional on our works
We must compete for God's favor
questions.correctAnswer: God values us uniquely, like a lily among thorns and an apple tree among wood
questions.explanation: The passage highlights God's special love by comparing the beloved to a lily among thorns and an apple tree among wood, showing believers their unique and cherished value (Song of Solomon 2:2-3; Romans 8:38-39; Zephaniah 3:17).

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 2:4 illustrate the importance of love and fellowship in Christian community?
options: Love is like a banner over us in fellowship and gatherings
Love should be hidden and secretive
questions.correctAnswer: Love is like a banner over us in fellowship and gatherings
questions.explanation: The verse describes being brought to the banqueting house with a banner of love, symbolizing how love should be openly displayed and central in Christian fellowship and worship (Song of Solomon 2:4; Hebrews 10:24-25; 1 Corinthians 13:1-3).

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with longing and emotional pain. What practical advice about spiritual comfort can be drawn from Song of Solomon 2:5?
options: Seek spiritual nourishment like comfort with apples and flagons
Rely only on self for healing
questions.correctAnswer: Seek spiritual nourishment like comfort with apples and flagons
questions.explanation: The verse metaphorically asks to be comforted with apples and flagons, symbolizing the importance of seeking God's sustaining presence and spiritual nourishment during trials (Song of Solomon 2:5; Psalm 23:5; Matthew 11:28-30).

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 2:7 teach about patience and trusting God's timing in relationships and prayer?
options: Do not stir or awaken love until it pleases God
Push for immediate answers and results
questions.correctAnswer: Do not stir or awaken love until it pleases God
questions.explanation: The verse advises waiting patiently for God's perfect timing rather than forcing things prematurely, emphasizing trust and obedience in relationships and prayer (Song of Solomon 2:7; Ecclesiastes 3:1; Psalm 27:14).

questions.question: True or False: According to Song of Solomon 2:8-9, the beloved is portrayed as strong and actively pursuing the beloved.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 8 and 9 describe the beloved coming leaping upon mountains and looking through the lattice, indicating an active pursuit and strength in love (Song of Solomon 2:8-9; Proverbs 18:22; Ephesians 5:25).

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 2:10-13 encourage believers to persevere through difficult seasons?
options: The passing of winter and the coming of spring symbolize hope and renewal
Trials never end and should be accepted passively
Seasons have no meaning in spiritual life
questions.correctAnswer: The passing of winter and the coming of spring symbolize hope and renewal
questions.explanation: The passage uses the imagery of winter passing and flowers appearing to remind believers that hard seasons end and God brings renewal, encouraging hope and perseverance (Song of Solomon 2:10-13; Romans 5:3-5; James 1:2-4).

questions.question: What biblical principle about intimacy and openness in marriage is taught in Song of Solomon 2:14?
options: Honest communication and desire to see and hear one's spouse
Marriage is only a social contract
questions.correctAnswer: Honest communication and desire to see and hear one's spouse
questions.explanation: The verse expresses a longing to see the beloved's face and hear their voice, teaching the importance of openness, communication, and affection in marriage (Song of Solomon 2:14; Ephesians 5:28-29; 1 Corinthians 7:3-5).

questions.question: A couple is facing challenges that threaten their unity. Based on Song of Solomon 2:15, what advice would you give about guarding their relationship?
options: Watch out for small problems (foxes) that can spoil the relationship
Ignore minor conflicts as they do not matter
questions.correctAnswer: Watch out for small problems (foxes) that can spoil the relationship
questions.explanation: The verse warns to take the little foxes that spoil the vines, symbolizing the need to address small issues early to protect the relationship (Song of Solomon 2:15; Proverbs 4:23; Ephesians 4:26-27).

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 2:16 teach about belonging and mutual commitment in marriage?
options: My beloved is mine, and I am his, emphasizing mutual belonging
questions.correctAnswer: My beloved is mine, and I am his, emphasizing mutual belonging
questions.explanation: The verse clearly states mutual belonging, teaching that marriage is a committed, reciprocal relationship based on love and fidelity (Song of Solomon 2:16; Ephesians 5:31; Mark 10:9).

questions.question: True or False: Song of Solomon 2:17 encourages believers to seek their beloved like a young hart on the mountains, symbolizing eagerness and spiritual pursuit.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse invites the beloved to be like a roe or young hart on the mountains, symbolizing eagerness and active pursuit, which can be applied to spiritual devotion and zeal (Song of Solomon 2:17; Psalm 42:1-2; Hebrews 12:1).

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 2:6 teach believers about physical affection and protection in marriage?
options: His left hand is under my head, and his right hand embraces me, showing care and protection
questions.correctAnswer: His left hand is under my head, and his right hand embraces me, showing care and protection
questions.explanation: The verse depicts tender physical affection and protection, teaching that marriage includes caring touch and security (Song of Solomon 2:6; 1 Corinthians 7:3-5; Ephesians 5:25).

questions.question: A believer is struggling with temptation that threatens their spiritual growth. Based on Song of Solomon 2:15, what practical principle can help them persevere?
options: Identify and remove small temptations early like little foxes that spoil vines
Ignore temptation and it will go away
Temptation is unavoidable and should not be resisted
Give in to temptation to avoid stress
questions.correctAnswer: Identify and remove small temptations early like little foxes that spoil vines
questions.explanation: The verse warns about little foxes spoiling vines, teaching believers to be vigilant and deal with minor temptations before they cause greater harm (Song of Solomon 2:15; James 1:14-15; 1 Corinthians 10:13).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Song of Solomon 2:12 says, 'The flowers appear on the earth; the time of the singing of birds is come, and the voice of the ______ is heard in our land.'
questions.correctAnswer: turtle
questions.explanation: The verse specifically mentions the voice of the turtle being heard, symbolizing the arrival of a joyful and renewing season (Song of Solomon 2:12).

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 2:3 teach about finding delight and satisfaction in a godly relationship?
options: Sitting under his shadow with great delight and tasting his sweet fruit
Looking for satisfaction only in material things
questions.correctAnswer: Sitting under his shadow with great delight and tasting his sweet fruit
questions.explanation: The verse portrays delight and satisfaction in the beloved's presence, teaching believers to find joy and contentment in godly relationships (Song of Solomon 2:3; Proverbs 5:18-19; Ecclesiastes 9:9).

hard.title: Song of Solomon Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Song of Solomon Chapter 2.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 2:1, the speaker identifies herself as the "rose of Sharon" and the "lily of the valleys." What is the likely symbolic meaning of these flowers in the ancient Near Eastern context?
questions.correctAnswer: Symbols of beauty and fertility
questions.explanation: The rose of Sharon and lily of the valleys are floral metaphors symbolizing beauty and fertility, common in Near Eastern poetry as seen in Song of Solomon 2:1.

questions.question: Song of Solomon 2:2 uses the imagery of a lily among thorns to describe the beloved. What literary device is primarily employed here?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: Verse 2 employs simile by comparing the beloved to a lily among thorns, highlighting purity and uniqueness amid adversity.

questions.question: What does the "apple tree among the trees of the wood" metaphor in Song of Solomon 2:3 suggest about the beloved in the cultural and literary context?
options: He is distinguished and provides shade and sustenance
questions.correctAnswer: He is distinguished and provides shade and sustenance
questions.explanation: The apple tree metaphor in verse 3 symbolizes the beloved's distinguished status and nurturing presence, as the speaker delights under his shadow and enjoys his fruit.

questions.question: According to Song of Solomon 2:4, what is the significance of the "banqueting house" and the "banner over me was love" in the ancient Near Eastern culture?
options: A place of celebration and public declaration of love
questions.correctAnswer: A place of celebration and public declaration of love
questions.explanation: The banqueting house in verse 4 is a place of joyful gathering, while the banner of love symbolizes a public and triumphant declaration of love, fitting the cultural context.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 2:5, the phrase "I am sick of love" uses what kind of figurative language to express intense emotion?
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor
questions.explanation: The expression "sick of love" in verse 5 is a metaphor conveying overwhelming passion affecting the speaker's physical and emotional state.

questions.question: The intimate physical description in Song of Solomon 2:6, "His left hand is under my head, and his right hand doth embrace me," best exemplifies which theme prevalent in this chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: Mutual affection and protection
questions.explanation: Verse 6 portrays physical closeness symbolizing mutual affection and protective intimacy, central to the chapter's theme of love.

questions.question: Song of Solomon 2:7 warns not to "stir up, nor awake my love, till he please." What does this caution reveal about the cultural norms regarding love and courtship?
options: Love should be patient and not forced
questions.correctAnswer: Love should be patient and not forced
questions.explanation: Verse 7 reflects a cultural ideal of waiting for the proper time in love, emphasizing patience and respect in courtship.

questions.question: True or False: In Song of Solomon 2:8-9, the beloved is portrayed as actively seeking the beloved, indicated by leaping on mountains and standing behind the wall.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 8 and 9 describe the beloved energetically approaching and looking from behind the wall, indicating active pursuit.

questions.question: What seasonal change is indicated in Song of Solomon 2:11-12 and how does it symbolically relate to the theme of love?
options: Winter to spring, symbolizing renewal and blossoming love
Spring to summer, symbolizing heat and conflict
questions.correctAnswer: Winter to spring, symbolizing renewal and blossoming love
questions.explanation: Verses 11-12 speak of winter passing and flowers appearing, symbolizing new life and growth that parallels the awakening of love.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 2:13, the fig tree and vines giving a good smell serve as a metaphor for what concept?
questions.correctAnswer: Fruitfulness and sweetness of love
questions.explanation: Verse 13 uses fruit-bearing trees with pleasant aroma as metaphors for the richness and pleasantness of love.

questions.question: The request in Song of Solomon 2:14 to see the "countenance" and hear the "voice" of the beloved emphasizes what aspect of their relationship?
options: The desire for intimate personal connection
questions.correctAnswer: The desire for intimate personal connection
questions.explanation: Verse 14 highlights the speaker's longing for direct, personal interaction, underscoring intimacy in love.

questions.question: What is the symbolic meaning of the "little foxes that spoil the vines" in Song of Solomon 2:15, especially in the context of ancient Israelite culture?
options: Small problems that can damage a loving relationship
questions.correctAnswer: Small problems that can damage a loving relationship
questions.explanation: Verse 15 uses foxes metaphorically to warn about minor issues that can cause significant harm to tender love, reflecting a cultural agricultural analogy.

questions.question: How does the mutual possession expressed in Song of Solomon 2:16, "My beloved is mine, and I am his," reflect the covenantal themes found elsewhere in Scripture?
options: It mirrors the covenant relationship of loyalty and belonging
questions.correctAnswer: It mirrors the covenant relationship of loyalty and belonging
questions.explanation: Verse 16's mutual belonging echoes biblical covenant language portraying exclusive, loyal relationships like those between God and Israel.

questions.question: The imagery in Song of Solomon 2:17 of the beloved being like a "roe or a young hart upon the mountains of Bether" primarily suggests what about the beloved's nature?
questions.correctAnswer: Gracefulness and alertness
questions.explanation: Verse 17 depicts the beloved as a swift and graceful animal, symbolizing vitality and watchfulness.

questions.question: Song of Solomon 2:10-13 contains a call to "Rise up, my love, my fair one, and come away." This invitation is an example of which poetic form commonly found in Hebrew love poetry?
questions.correctAnswer: An invitation or summons
questions.explanation: Verses 10-13 feature the beloved summoning the loved one to enjoy the renewal of spring, a classic form of Hebrew poetic invitation.

theological.title: Song of Solomon Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Song of Solomon Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 2:1, the speaker identifies herself as which two symbolic flowers?
options: Rose of Sharon and lily of the valleys
Lily of the field and rose of Jericho
Cedar of Lebanon and olive tree
Hyssop on the wall and almond tree
questions.correctAnswer: Rose of Sharon and lily of the valleys
questions.explanation: The speaker says, 'I am the rose of Sharon, and the lily of the valleys,' symbolizing beauty and purity (Song of Solomon 2:1). This imagery aligns with how flowers often symbolize divine beauty and grace, similar to how Jesus is referred to as the 'Rose of Sharon' in Christian typology (Isaiah 35:1; Matthew 6:28-29; Hosea 14:5; John 15:1).

questions.question: How does the beloved compare himself to nature in Song of Solomon 2:3?
options: Apple tree among the trees of the wood
questions.correctAnswer: Apple tree among the trees of the wood
questions.explanation: The beloved is compared to an apple tree among the trees of the wood, showing his uniqueness and desirability (Song of Solomon 2:3). This metaphor recalls Psalm 1:3 about a fruitful tree and Christ as the true vine (John 15:1), emphasizing sustenance and delight.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'his banner over me was love' in Song of Solomon 2:4 signify theologically?
options: The protecting presence of divine love
A call to war against sin
questions.correctAnswer: The protecting presence of divine love
questions.explanation: The image of a banner of love symbolizes God's protective and prevailing love for His people (Song of Solomon 2:4). This correlates with God's steadfast love in the Old Testament (Exodus 15:2; Zephaniah 3:17) and New Testament teachings on love as the greatest virtue (1 Corinthians 13:13; Romans 8:37-39).

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 2:5, what does the speaker request to be comforted with, and what is the reason given?
options: Flagons and apples because she is sick of love
Honey and wine because she is joyful
Bread and water because she is hungry
Oil and incense because she is anointed
questions.correctAnswer: Flagons and apples because she is sick of love
questions.explanation: The speaker asks to be sustained with flagons and comforted with apples because she is 'sick of love' (Song of Solomon 2:5), portraying the intensity and sometimes the anguish of divine love, similar to the longing expressed in Psalm 42:1-2 and the soul's thirst for God (John 4:13-14).

questions.question: What posture of intimacy is described in Song of Solomon 2:6?
options: His left hand under my head and his right hand embracing me
They walk hand in hand through the garden
He lifts her up in his arms
They sit side by side watching the stars
questions.correctAnswer: His left hand under my head and his right hand embracing me
questions.explanation: The beloved’s left hand under her head and the right hand embracing her (Song of Solomon 2:6) symbolize tender care and intimate protection, reflecting Christ’s loving embrace of the Church (Ephesians 5:25-27; John 10:28-29; Isaiah 40:11).

questions.question: According to Song of Solomon 2:7, what command is given regarding the beloved?
options: Do not stir up or awaken my love until he pleases
Call him loudly to come quickly
Prepare a feast in his honor
Build a wall around the garden
questions.correctAnswer: Do not stir up or awaken my love until he pleases
questions.explanation: The speaker charges the daughters of Jerusalem not to awaken her love until he pleases (Song of Solomon 2:7), emphasizing divine timing in love and the Spirit’s work (Ecclesiastes 3:1; John 3:8; Revelation 3:20; 2 Timothy 2:24).

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 2:8-9, how is the beloved described in his movement and appearance?
options: Leaping upon mountains and standing behind the wall
Riding a chariot through the valley
questions.correctAnswer: Leaping upon mountains and standing behind the wall
questions.explanation: The beloved is depicted leaping on mountains and standing behind the wall looking through the lattice (Song of Solomon 2:8-9), symbolizing both his strength and his desire to seek out the beloved, echoing God's pursuit of His people (Isaiah 40:31; Ezekiel 34:11-16; Luke 15:4-6).

questions.question: What invitation does the beloved extend in Song of Solomon 2:10?
options: Rise up, my love, my fair one, and come away
Stay here and rest beside me
Prepare the banquet for all to see
Sing a new song of praise
questions.correctAnswer: Rise up, my love, my fair one, and come away
questions.explanation: The beloved invites the beloved to rise and come away (Song of Solomon 2:10), a call to spiritual awakening and union with Christ, paralleling calls in Isaiah 51:1-2 and Revelation 22:17 for the bride to come to the marriage supper of the Lamb.

questions.question: Which seasonal change is described in Song of Solomon 2:11-12 as the reason to arise and come away?
options: Winter is past, flowers appear, and birds sing
Summer heat is intense, and rivers dry up
Autumn leaves fall, and harvest begins
Spring rains descend, and floods rise
questions.correctAnswer: Winter is past, flowers appear, and birds sing
questions.explanation: The text states that winter is past, flowers appear, and birds sing (Song of Solomon 2:11-12), symbolizing renewal and resurrection, consistent with biblical themes of new life in Christ (Psalm 98:7-8; Ecclesiastes 3:1; Hosea 6:3; 1 Peter 1:3).

questions.question: What natural imagery does Song of Solomon 2:13 use to describe the time of coming away?
options: Fig tree putting forth green figs and vines giving a good smell
Cedars growing tall on the mountains
questions.correctAnswer: Fig tree putting forth green figs and vines giving a good smell
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 2:13 describes the fig tree putting forth green figs and vines with tender grapes giving a good smell, symbolizing fruitfulness and blessing, resonating with biblical themes of God's provision (Joel 2:22; Jeremiah 24:2; John 15:5; Revelation 22:2).

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 2:14, how does the beloved address the beloved, and what does he request?
options: O my dove in the rock clefts; let me see thy countenance and hear thy voice
My sister, come dance with me in the vineyards
My bride, prepare the feast for our friends
My chosen, rise and shine like the morning star
questions.correctAnswer: O my dove in the rock clefts; let me see thy countenance and hear thy voice
questions.explanation: The beloved calls the beloved 'O my dove' in hidden places and requests to see her countenance and hear her voice (Song of Solomon 2:14), expressing intimate fellowship and the beauty of communion, reflecting Christ’s desire for the Church’s intimacy (Psalm 84:3; Ezekiel 34:12; John 10:14; Song of Solomon 5:2).

questions.question: What warning is given in Song of Solomon 2:15, and what does it symbolize?
options: Take us the little foxes that spoil the vines, symbolizing small sins that harm love
Beware of wild beasts in the forest, symbolizing spiritual enemies
Guard the gates at dawn, symbolizing vigilance in prayer
Keep the lamps burning, symbolizing readiness for the bridegroom
questions.correctAnswer: Take us the little foxes that spoil the vines, symbolizing small sins that harm love
questions.explanation: The warning to 'take us the little foxes that spoil the vines' (Song of Solomon 2:15) symbolizes how small, unchecked sins can spoil relationships and spiritual fruitfulness, consistent with biblical admonitions (Ecclesiastes 10:1; James 3:5-6; Proverbs 6:27-29; Galatians 5:9).

questions.question: What mutual belonging is expressed in Song of Solomon 2:16?
options: My beloved is mine, and I am his
We are strangers until the appointed time
I am the servant, and he is the master
They are two but become one
questions.correctAnswer: My beloved is mine, and I am his
questions.explanation: The mutual belonging 'My beloved is mine, and I am his' (Song of Solomon 2:16) reflects the profound covenantal union between Christ and the Church (Ephesians 5:31-32; John 10:27-28; 2 Corinthians 11:2; Revelation 21:9).

questions.question: What metaphor is used in Song of Solomon 2:17 to describe the beloved’s movement until daybreak?
options: Be like a roe or a young hart upon the mountains of Bether
Fly like an eagle over the valleys
Run swiftly as a gazelle through the fields
Stand firm as a cedar in Lebanon
questions.correctAnswer: Be like a roe or a young hart upon the mountains of Bether
questions.explanation: The beloved is urged to be like a roe or a young hart on the mountains of Bether until daybreak (Song of Solomon 2:17), symbolizing agility, alertness, and divine protection, paralleling biblical images of God’s care (Psalm 42:1; Habakkuk 3:19; Isaiah 40:31; 2 Samuel 22:34).

questions.question: What theological theme is emphasized by the repeated call not to awaken love until it pleases in Song of Solomon 2:7 and 2:13?
options: The sovereignty of divine timing in love and salvation
The necessity of human effort to initiate love
The importance of ritual purity before love
questions.correctAnswer: The sovereignty of divine timing in love and salvation
questions.explanation: The call not to awaken love until it pleases (Song of Solomon 2:7 and implied in 2:13) highlights God's sovereign timing in love and salvation, consistent with scriptural teaching on God's perfect timing (Ecclesiastes 3:1; Galatians 4:4; 2 Timothy 1:9; Romans 8:28).
